work.p: This manuscript may relate distantly to a line in the 1855 preface to Leaves of Grass: "Who recruits him recruits horse and foot . . . he fetches parks of artillery the best that engineer ever knew."

These lines match a line in a notebook that also contains draft lines of a poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures": "And now a ^merry recruiter passes, with fife and drum, seeking who will join his troop." The first several lines of the notebook (not including this line) were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

a machine readable transcription

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: The sores on my shoulders are from his
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Lines on the back of this leaf relate to the poem eventually titled "The Sleepers."

lg.l: Hear my fife!—I am a recruiter
Who Come, who will join my troop?
